No change to previous policy. All public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro is provided detailed information on congestion for each train line and train station at each hour.  Regular service continues on Japan Rail with heightened prevention measures including increase ventilation, physical distancing, disinfection, wearing of masks, and preventing passengers from rotating seats.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008203649/https://www.tokyometro.jp/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008203659/https://tmap-sid.tokyometro.jp/o/view/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008203925/https://www.westjr.co.jp/info/corona_taisaku.html

The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates and to cooperate with the night-time business closures at 9:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008202753/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008202753/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204034/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204828/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C127.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204046/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203912/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1, p.34).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205132/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205132/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205235/https://corona.go.jp/action

Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205419/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205414/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814025731/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/data-widget/ (Dashboard properly loads in the non-archived version)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210731043406/https://www.stopcovid19.jp/ (Data properly loads in the non-archived version)

No change to previous policy.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people, e.g. schools. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative rapid antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigent testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205543/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205549/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205625/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205304/https://hiro-clinic.jp/

No change to previous policy.  There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the number of infections and the resources required. Close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008210133/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/osaka/news/20211004-OYTNT50138/ (contact tracing in Hikata, Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008210247/https://www.fnn.jp/articles/-/249325 (contact tracing in Fujinomiya, Shizuoka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212109/https://news.line.me/articles/oa-jolf/0d358cd69958 (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008210026/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212307/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212314/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.html

On October 4, walk-in (no reservation) vaccinations begin for residents 16 years old and up at mass vaccination venues in Osaka Prefecture.  On October 4, Tokyo begins vaccinating residents 12 years old and up for those who have reserved slots at mass vaccination sites in Tokyo Metropolitan Area.    Third dose vaccinations is being planned to begin in December 2021.  As of Oct 8, 72.8% of the total population in Japan (including those under the eligible age for vaccination) have received their first dose, with 63.1% of the total population having received both doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213231/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213225/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211006/k10013294641000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213929/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211004/k10013290701000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213451/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291661000.html (third doses)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182806/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/

No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of September 10, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212418/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212436/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212436/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/
